thread.title: So far, so good, MLGW leader says about few power outages | News | fox13memphis.com
thread.title_full: So far, so good, MLGW leader says about few power outages | News | fox13memphis.com

author: @https://twitter.com/FOX13Memphis
title: So far, so good, MLGW leader says about few power outages | News | fox13memphis.com
text:
So far, so good, MLGW leader says about few power outages during storm FOX13 Memphis News Staff FOX13 Memphis News Staff Author facebook Author twitter Author email Jan 15, 2024 2 hrs ago Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email WATCH: MLGW's CEO talks utility company's response to winter blast across the Mid-South
Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Save Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Save MEMPHIS, Tenn. - The head of Memphis Light Gas & Water (MLGW) said that efforts to trim tree branches over the past several weeks directly contributed to the few number of power outages, so far, during the winter storm.
MLGW President & CEO Doug McGowen talked about current utility conditions LIVE on Good Morning Memphis on Monday, Jan. 15.
However, there exists the likelihood, he forecasted, for a voluntary electric conservation alert to be issued possibly Tuesday and Wednesday.
That alert would ask MLGW customers to turn the power off of any unnecessary electrical items, such as lights in the home, and avoid using large appliances such as a washer or dryer.
The move would be prompted by usage strains on the national electrical grid from the winter blast affecting much of the country.
RELATED : Power outages are major concerns as Mid-South residents prepare for storms
As of Monday morning, almost all customers had power despite several inches of snow and freezing temperatures.
"We have been at this moment in a winter storm in the past, and you couldn't make out the (high) number of power outages on the map," FOX13 Anchor Ernie Freeman told McGowen.
"It's looking very good, the team is staying on top of any problems during arduous conditions," McGowen said.
The past few days also saw wind gusts come through the area, but McGowen said MLGW workers addressed and repaired outages quickly.
McGowen said the equivalent of 500 miles of vegetation out of 4,500 miles needing cut has been cleared since regrouped efforts were made to address the neglected issues about two months ago.
He said workers are ahead of schedule on the tree trimming, working hard to get even further ahead.
In response to Anchor Val Calhoun's comments about customers being proactive during troublesome weather, McGowen encouraged residents to cover faucets, including outdoor ones, and for store owners, whose businesses are closed today for the holiday, to visit and check on pipes.
"We are at a really good position," right now with power, McGowen said. "But the longer we go with the deep freeze, the higher the likelihood that something will break at home or at a business, or there will be a water main break."
